awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Sameer Iyer is "Several problems in the mathematical theory of fluid flows." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University and the sponsoring scientist is Alexandru Ionescu.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the major problems in fluid dynamics is to understand the vanishing viscosity, or high Reynolds number, limit for the Navier-Stokes (NS) equations in the presence of physical boundaries. Due to the generic mismatch between the no-slip condition imposed for NS and the no-penetration condition imposed for Euler, this limit gives rise to the formation of boundary layers, a classical physical phenomenon. A thorough understanding of this limit is required for applications, since reduced models such as the Prandtl system are used to approximate real Navier-Stokes flows. 

During the grant period, the PI obtained several significant results regarding the stability and refined properties of the Prandtl boundary layer. 

In the first direction, the PI gave (in collaborative work) the first rigorous proof of validity of the famous Prandtl expansion for stationary Navier-Stokes flows (in Sobolev spaces) which is valid for the classical Blasius profiles, which are observed in experiments. This result was local in x, which behaves like a time variable that indexes the position of the flow.

The PI subsequently (also in collaborative work) gave a proof of global asymptotic stability of these Blasius profiles, which matches famous physical experiments that show the stability (and lack of boundary layer separation) in certain regimes.

The PI then studied (in collaborative work) the complementary regime: one in which boundary layer separation can occur. This regime is generic; it was identified by Prandtl in his orignal work in 1904. In this regime, the PI worked to study the stability properties of reversed flows: when the tangential velocity can change sign. This corresponds to famous physical pictures one sees (for instance, flows over a tennis ball or airplane wing). Nevertheless, a mathematical characterization of flow reversal is extermely challenging, due to the mixed-type nature of Prandtl equations. The PI worked with collaborators to develop a mathematical framework to study these nonlocal, mixed-type equations, which has the potential to apply to many other problems in fluid dynamics.

During the grant period, the PI studied the so-called Triple-Deck model, which is also a classical refinement of the Prandtl theory that is supposed to serve as valid reduced model for Navier-Stokes flows near boundary layer separation. The PI then collaborated to prove the only two known rigorous mathematical results on this model, which opens the door to a more detailed understanding for boundary layer separation for the Navier-Stokes equations.     

The PI also collaborated with others at Princeton on various projects, such as self-similar blowup for compressible Euler. 

The work of the PI led to eleven publications/ preprints, many of which are significant and detailed stability results.  Additionally the research findings funded by the grant was disseminated by the PI in twenty-four seminar, colloquium, and conference talks. In addition, the PI co-organized the Analysis of Fluids and Related Topics seminar at Princeton University, a weekly seminar, from 2018-2021. The PI also discussed the research findings in three outreach talks aimed at attracting undergraduates and early graduate students to this research discipline.
